definition.primary: Sudden onset of acute pulmonary edema due to bilateral renal artery stenosis or unilateral stenosis in a solitary kidney, caused by impaired sodium excretion and neurohormonal activation leading to volume overload. Also known as Pickering syndrome.
key_concepts: Distinct clinical syndrome indicating renovascular cause of hypertension
Occurs in bilateral RAS or stenosis to solitary/dominant kidney
Results from inability to excrete sodium load (pressure natriuresis failure)
Strong indication for revascularization unlike many other RAS presentations

mechanism.primary: Bilateral renal artery stenosis activates renin-angiotensin system in both kidneys, preventing normal pressure natriuresis
mechanism.normal_response: Elevated BP normally causes natriuresis via contralateral kidney
mechanism.in_bilateral_ras: Both kidneys perceive underperfusion, retain sodium regardless of BP

precipitants: ACE inhibitor initiation (especially in bilateral RAS)

associated_findings.diastolic_dysfunction: Common in these patients, exacerbates edema

epidemiology.prevalence: Present in 10-20% of patients with bilateral RAS

classic_features.timing: Often nocturnal (PND) or with minimal exertion

classic_features.pattern: Multiple hospitalizations for 'CHF' with preserved EF

classic_features.observation: Diuretics, BP medications don't prevent recurrence

classic_features.bp: Often severely elevated BP at presentation

clues_to_renovascular_etiology: Known bilateral renal artery stenosis or small kidneys
Recurrent flash pulmonary edema without coronary ischemia
Rise in creatinine with ACE inhibitors

workup.purpose: Assess kidney sizes, renal artery velocities
workup.findings: Elevated PSV (> 200 cm/s), RAR > 3.5, small kidneys bilaterally
Significant stenosis bilaterally or to solitary kidney

workup.purpose: Assess LV function, diastolic dysfunction, valvular disease
workup.typical: Preserved EF with diastolic dysfunction, LVH

workup.purpose: Confirm volume overload, exclude non-cardiac cause

required: Bilateral renal artery stenosis â‰¥ 60% (or unilateral to functioning kidney)

caution: ACE inhibitors may worsen renal function acutely
Aggressive diuresis may precipitate renal failure

revascularization.indication: Flash pulmonary edema is one of strongest indications for RAS intervention

options.outcomes: 70-80% reduction in recurrent pulmonary edema episodes

options.preferred_when: Failed stenting, complex anatomy, need for concurrent aortic surgery

unilateral_vs_bilateral.timing: May stage bilateral stenting or treat simultaneously

with_revascularization: Significant reduction in pulmonary edema episodes (70-80%)
Variable effect on renal function (may stabilize, rarely improves)

key_studies.limitation: Did not specifically include flash pulmonary edema patients
key_studies.conclusion: General RAS stenting trials did not show benefit, but flash PE is recognized exception

key_studies.finding: Consistent benefit of revascularization for flash pulmonary edema specifically

evidence_base.guideline_position: Most guidelines recognize flash pulmonary edema as indication for RAS intervention despite negative general trials

learning_objectives: Understand the pathophysiology of flash pulmonary edema in bilateral RAS
Recognize clinical clues suggesting renovascular etiology
Determine when revascularization is indicated for RAS
Understand why flash PE is an exception to general RAS treatment recommendations
key_points: Flash pulmonary edema occurs with bilateral RAS or stenosis to solitary kidney
Mechanism is failure of pressure natriuresis leading to volume overload
Preserved EF with recurrent pulmonary edema should raise suspicion
One of the few accepted indications for renal artery revascularization
70-80% reduction in episodes after successful stenting
clinical_pearls: Think of bilateral RAS in elderly patient with 'unexplained' recurrent flash pulmonary edema and preserved EF
Rise in creatinine with ACE inhibitors is clue to bilateral RAS
Don't apply CORAL/ASTRAL results to flash pulmonary edema patients - they were excluded
May need ultrafiltration as bridge to revascularization

references.evidence_basis: Observational studies, physiological studies, case series
references.historical_note: First described by Pickering et al. in 1988
